content.description: This is a beautiful, steep face with reachy moves, flexibility is key so stretch out.
content.location:
This is located at the south end of the Universal Crag, up slope and around the corner from

Fighting Irish

and

Palm Pilot

.

content.description:
This route starts between

Equator

and the

Magna Headwall

in the obvious tight hand crack. Step across and pull into the tight angling crack and make difficult moves (crux) to an alcove. Climb the finger crack directly above the alcove for a few moves to access the angling tight hand crack and follow it to the anchors of

Equator

.

Right of

Dozey Brat

in a small dihedral. Sit start and climb to the sloping top. Great rock.
content.protection: One Drop Zone, though the fall could be odd, into a boulder nest/the creek.

climbs.name: Palm Pilot
climbs.fa: Jim Redo, bolted and modified by Mark Rolofson & John Baldwin

content.description:
First of all, let me say that I did not chip this route. I did not equip this route. It was an open project, and I just free climbed this route. I re-named the route to "Palm Pilot" from "Victoria's Secret". It ain't no secret, boys, ya chipped a hold. This route is on the far left side of the crag left of an open corner. It is an extremely overhanging arete.

Scramble up a 3rd class slab for 30 feet to the first bolt. Clip another bolt and move out left to a ledge where you can sit. The climbing basically starts here. Varied climbing for 2 bolts brings you to the first crux. Powerful slaps and a pinch to a chipped horn. It ain't over. One very big move and a bit of 5.12 bring you to the anchor. 24 moves...not a path.
content.protection: 8 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor. There is a stray bolt next to the 7th bolt.

climbs.name: Magna Headwall
climbs.fa: Bob Horan. FFA: Bob Horan, fall 1998, with Jen Cook

content.description:
Magna Headwall climbs an attractive, concave feature in the middle of the crag that steepens considerably at the top.  The final 15 feet comprise the crimpy and dynamic crux which utilizes several criss-crossing cracks.  Unfortunately, three holds have been enhanced, turning what may have been an excellent natural route into a so-so chipped route.

It still deserves a star because it's an eye-catching line with good position and fun moves.
content.protection: Seven bolts to a two-bolt anchor.

climbs.name: Fighting Irish
climbs.fa: FFA: Bob Horan, spring 1997, with Mark Kalin

content.description:
This pitch is one route right of

Palm Pilot

. It packs a bloody, powerful punch in under 15 moves. Ascend a 25 foot slab to get to the real climbing. Clip a couple of directional bolts to keep the rope out of your way, then head up the dihedral. Sidepull and stem your way up for four bolts to the anchors.
content.protection: Six bolts to a two bolt anchor.

content.description:
Climb the prominent, leaning, crack system right of

Dream Machine

, left of the

Magna Headwall

. Climb up from the pillar, up and right following the obtuse dihedral and crack, turn the bulge, reaching and surmounting out left to the two bolt anchor. It has 8 bolts.
content.location:
Climb the prominent, leaning, crack system right of

Dream Machine

, left of the

Magna Headwall

. Climb up from the pillar, up and right follwing the obtuse dihedral and crack.

content.description:
Climbs the jutting overhang on left side of Universal Crag, left of

Equator

right of

Fighting Irish

.  Climb up to the roof, 5.12b/c, then up and out to headwall, 5.11, to a two bolt anchor. 8 bolts.
content.location:
Climbs the jutting overhang on left side of Universal Crag, left of

Equator

right of

Fighting Irish

.

content.description: This is a technical, vertical climb on great stone with really fun moves.
content.protection: A single Drop Zone for the start, a fall would deposit you in the creek after maybe bouncing off the boulder!
content.location: This boulder sits at the rivers edge just by the Universal Crag.

content.description: Start sitting with poor-ish holds, do a tough toss to a nasty crimp/edge RH. Squeeze up the blunt prow and mantle.
content.location: Obvious short prow on the right side of the Dr. West Boulder.
